summary.long: Song Of Solomon is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth—
For your love is better than wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Draw me away!
We will run after you.
The king has brought me into his chambers.
We will be glad and rejoice in you. 
We will remember your love more than wine.
Rightly do they love you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am dark, but lovely,
O daughters of Jerusalem,
Like the tents of Kedar,
Like the curtains of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not look upon me, because I am dark,
Because the sun has tanned me.
My mother’s sons were angry with me;
They made me the keeper of the vineyards,
But my own vineyard I have not kept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell me, O you whom I love,
Where you feed your flock,
Where you make it rest at noon.
For why should I be as one who veils herself
By the flocks of your companions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do not know, O fairest among women,
Follow in the footsteps of the flock,
And feed your little goats
Beside the shepherds’ tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have compared you, my love,
To my filly among Pharaoh’s chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your cheeks are lovely with ornaments,
Your neck with chains of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We will make you ornaments of gold
With studs of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While the king is at his table,
My spikenard sends forth its fragrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A bundle of myrrh is my beloved to me,
That lies all night between my breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blooms
In the vineyards of En Gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, you are fair, my love!
Behold, you are fair!
You have dove’s eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, you are handsome, my beloved!
Yes, pleasant!
Also our bed is green.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The beams of our houses are cedar,
And our rafters of fir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am the rose of Sharon,
And the lily of the valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a lily among thorns,
So is my love among the daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an apple tree among the trees of the woods,
So is my beloved among the sons.
I sat down in his shade with great delight,
And his fruit was sweet to my taste.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brought me to the banqueting house,
And his banner over me was love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sustain me with cakes of raisins,
Refresh me with apples,
For I am lovesick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His left hand is under my head,
And his right hand embraces me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
By the gazelles or by the does of the field,
Do not stir up nor awaken love
Until it pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The voice of my beloved!
Behold, he comes
Leaping upon the mountains,
Skipping upon the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag.
Behold, he stands behind our wall;
He is looking through the windows,
Gazing through the lattice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved spoke, and said to me:
“Rise up, my love, my fair one,
And come away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For lo, the winter is past,
The rain is over and gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The flowers appear on the earth;
The time of singing has come,
And the voice of the turtledove
Is heard in our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fig tree puts forth her green figs,
And the vines with the tender grapes
Give a good smell.
Rise up, my love, my fair one,
And come away!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“O my dove, in the clefts of the rock,
In the secret places of the cliff,
Let me see your face,
Let me hear your voice;
For your voice is sweet,
And your face is lovely.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Catch us the foxes,
The little foxes that spoil the vines,
For our vines have tender grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is mine, and I am his.
He feeds his flock among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breaks
And the shadows flee away,
Turn, my beloved,
And be like a gazelle
Or a young stag
Upon the mountains of Bether.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By night on my bed I sought the one I love;
I sought him, but I did not find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will rise now,” I said,
“And go about the city;
In the streets and in the squares
I will seek the one I love.”
I sought him, but I did not find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Scarcely had I passed by them,
When I found the one I love.
I held him and would not let him go,
Until I had brought him to the house of my mother,
And into the chamber of her who conceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
By the gazelles or by the does of the field,
Do not stir up nor awaken love
Until it pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this coming out of the wilderness
Like pillars of smoke,
Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
With all the merchant’s fragrant powders?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, it is Solomon’s couch,
With sixty valiant men around it,
Of the valiant of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They all hold swords,
Being expert in war.
Every man has his sword on his thigh
Because of fear in the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Of the wood of Lebanon
Solomon the King
Made himself a palanquin:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made its pillars of silver,
Its support of gold,
Its seat of purple,
Its interior paved with love
By the daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go forth, O daughters of Zion,
And see King Solomon with the crown
With which his mother crowned him
On the day of his wedding,
The day of the gladness of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, you are fair, my love!
Behold, you are fair!
You have dove’s eyes behind your veil.
Your hair is like a flock of goats,
Going down from Mount Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of shorn sheep
Which have come up from the washing,
Every one of which bears twins,
And none is barren among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your lips are like a strand of scarlet,
And your mouth is lovely.
Your temples behind your veil
Are like a piece of pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like the tower of David,
Built for an armory,
On which hang a thousand bucklers,
All shields of mighty men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
Twins of a gazelle,
Which feed among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breaks
And the shadows flee away,
I will go my way to the mountain of myrrh
And to the hill of frankincense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are all fair, my love,
And there is no spot in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse,
With me from Lebanon.
Look from the top of Amana,
From the top of Senir and Hermon,
From the lions’ dens,
From the mountains of the leopards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have ravished my heart,
My sister, my spouse;
You have ravished my heart
With one look of your eyes,
With one link of your necklace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How fair is your love,
My sister, my spouse!
How much better than wine is your love,
And the scent of your perfumes
Than all spices!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
A garden enclosed
Is my sister, my spouse,
A spring shut up,
A fountain sealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your plants are an orchard of pomegranates
With pleasant fruits,
Fragrant henna with spikenard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Spikenard and saffron,
Calamus and cinnamon,
With all trees of frankincense,
Myrrh and aloes,
With all the chief spices—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fountain of gardens,
A well of living waters,
And streams from Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Awake, O north wind,
And come, O south!
Blow upon my garden,
That its spices may flow out.
Let my beloved come to his garden
And eat its pleasant fruits.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I sleep, but my heart is awake;
It is the voice of my beloved!
He knocks, saying,
“Open for me, my sister, my love,
My dove, my perfect one;
For my head is covered with dew,
My locks with the drops of the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved put his hand
By the latch of the door,
And my heart yearned for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I arose to open for my beloved,
And my hands dripped with myrrh,
My fingers with liquid myrrh,
On the handles of the lock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I opened for my beloved,
But my beloved had turned away and was gone.
My heart leaped up when he spoke.
I sought him, but I could not find him;
I called him, but he gave me no answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchmen who went about the city found me.
They struck me, they wounded me;
The keepers of the walls
Took my veil away from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
If you find my beloved,
That you tell him I am lovesick!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is your beloved
More than another beloved,
O fairest among women?
What is your beloved
More than another beloved,
That you so charge us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is white and ruddy,
Chief among ten thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes are like doves
By the rivers of waters,
Washed with milk,
And fitly set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His cheeks are like a bed of spices,
Banks of scented herbs.
His lips are lilies,
Dripping liquid myrrh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His hands are rods of gold
Set with beryl.
His body is carved ivory
Inlaid with sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His legs are pillars of marble
Set on bases of fine gold.
His countenance is like Lebanon,
Excellent as the cedars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His mouth is most sweet,
Yes, he is altogether lovely.
This is my beloved,
And this is my friend,
O daughters of Jerusalem!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where has your beloved gone,
O fairest among women?
Where has your beloved turned aside,
That we may seek him with you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved has gone to his garden,
To the beds of spices,
To feed his flock in the gardens,
And to gather lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am my beloved’s,
And my beloved is mine.
He feeds his flock among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O my love, you are as beautiful as Tirzah,
Lovely as Jerusalem,
Awesome as an army with banners!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn your eyes away from me,
For they have overcome me.
Your hair is like a flock of goats
Going down from Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of sheep
Which have come up from the washing;
Every one bears twins,
And none is barren among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a piece of pomegranate
Are your temples behind your veil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are sixty queens
And eighty concubines,
And virgins without number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My dove, my perfect one,
Is the only one,
The only one of her mother,
The favorite of the one who bore her.
The daughters saw her
And called her blessed,
The queens and the concubines,
And they praised her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is she who looks forth as the morning,
Fair as the moon,
Clear as the sun,
Awesome as an army with banners?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I went down to the garden of nuts
To see the verdure of the valley,
To see whether the vine had budded
And the pomegranates had bloomed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before I was even aware,
My soul had made me
As the chariots of my noble people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Return, return, O Shulamite;
Return, return, that we may look upon you!
What would you see in the Shulamite—
As it were, the dance of the two camps?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
O prince’s daughter!
The curves of your thighs are like jewels,
The work of the hands of a skillful workman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your navel is a rounded goblet;
It lacks no blended beverage.
Your waist is a heap of wheat
Set about with lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
Twins of a gazelle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like an ivory tower,
Your eyes like the pools in Heshbon
By the gate of Bath Rabbim.
Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon
Which looks toward Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
How fair and how pleasant you are,
O love, with your delights!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This stature of yours is like a palm tree,
And your breasts like its clusters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I said, “I will go up to the palm tree,
I will take hold of its branches.”
Let now your breasts be like clusters of the vine,
The fragrance of your breath like apples,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And the roof of your mouth like the best wine.
The wine goes down smoothly for my beloved,
Moving gently the lips of sleepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am my beloved’s,
And his desire is toward me.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Let us get up early to the vineyards;
Let us see if the vine has budded,
Whether the grape blossoms are open,
And the pomegranates are in bloom.
There I will give you my love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mandrakes give off a fragrance,
And at our gates are pleasant fruits,
All manner, new and old,
Which I have laid up for you, my beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, that you were like my brother,
Who nursed at my mother’s breasts!
If I should find you outside,
I would kiss you;
I would not be despised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would lead you and bring you
Into the house of my mother,
She who used to instruct me.
I would cause you to drink of spiced wine,
Of the juice of my pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His left hand is under my head,
And his right hand embraces me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
Do not stir up nor awaken love
Until it pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this coming up from the wilderness,
Leaning upon her beloved? 
I awakened you under the apple tree.
There your mother brought you forth;
There she who bore you brought you forth.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
Nor can the floods drown it.
If a man would give for love
All the wealth of his house,
It would be utterly despised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have a little sister,
And she has no breasts.
What shall we do for our sister
In the day when she is spoken for?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If she is a wall,
We will build upon her
A battlement of silver;
And if she is a door,
We will enclose her
With boards of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am a wall,
And my breasts like towers;
Then I became in his eyes
As one who found peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
My own vineyard is before me.
You, O Solomon, may have a thousand,
And those who tend its fruit two hundred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who dwell in the gardens,
The companions listen for your voice—
Let me hear it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Make haste, my beloved,
And be like a gazelle
Or a young stag
On the mountains of spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator
